name: spizella-passerina
definition: The chipping sparrow  is a species of American sparrow, a passerine bird in the family Passerellidae.
description:
It is widespread, fairly tame, and common across most of its North American range.

This bird is a partial migrant with northerly populations flying southwards in the fall to overwinter in Mexico.

Throughout the year, adults are gray below and an orangish-rust color above.

Adults in breeding plumage have a reddish cap, a nearly white supercilium, and a black trans-ocular line.

Adults in nonbreeding plumage are less prominently marked, with a brownish cap, a dusky eyebrow, and a dark eye-line.

The brownish cap and dusky eyebrow are variable but generally obscure in juveniles.

The chipping sparrow feeds on seeds year-round, although insects form most of the diet in the breeding season.

Common dandelion seeds are important during spring, but this sparrow diet includes seeds from black-bindweed, honey clover, chickweed, lamb's quarters, and common wild oat.

Spiders are sometimes taken.

Throughout the year, chipping sparrows forage on the ground in covered areas, often near the edges of fields.

The male chipping sparrow start arriving at the breeding grounds from March to mid-May. The female arrives one to two weeks later, and the male starts singing soon after to find and court a mate.

After pair formation, nesting begins - within about two weeks of the female's arrival. Overall, the breeding season is from March till about August.

Chipping sparrows have long been considered largely monogamous. However, polygyny and extra pair copulations are documented.

The chipping sparrow breeds in grassy, open woodland clearings and shrubby grass fields.

The nest is constructed by the female in about four days.

It consists of a loose platform of grass and rootlets and open inner cup of plant fiber and animal hair.

The nest is normally above ground but below 6 meters in height, in a tree - usually short and thick conifer, or a bush.

The chipping sparrow lays a clutch of two to seven pale blue to white eggs with black, brown, or purple markings.

Eggs are about 17 by 12 millimeters in size, and incubated by the female for 10 to 15 days.

This sparrow song is a trill that varies considerably among birds within any particular region.

Two broad classes of variation in the song of the chipping sparrow are the fast trill and the slow trill.

Individual elements in the fast trill are run together about twice as fast as in the slow trill; the fast trill sounds like a buzz or like someone snoring, whereas the slow trill sounds like rapid finger-tapping.

Individual elements in the trill are very similar to a high pitch chi chi chi call.

related.definition: The house sparrow is a bird of the sparrow family Passeridae, found in most parts of the world.
A widely distributed bird that nests in barns and caves and has a deeply forked tail, a dark-blue back, and tan underparts.
The common house martin is a migratory passerine bird of the swallow family.
The American goldfinch is a small North American bird in the finch family.
